text: At least once a week I think "Why don't I code more in Rust? I should code something up quick to get better at it", and then, 30 minutes later, I'm like, "Oh, that was why".

elements.text: At least once a week I think "Why don't I code more in Rust? I should code something up quick to get better at it", and then, 30 minutes later, I'm like, "Oh, that was why".

text: I've been writing Rust for a little while now I'm having a lot of fun. Wish I had more time to put into it.

elements.text: I've been writing Rust for a little while now I'm having a lot of fun. Wish I had more time to put into it.

text: people say that it doesn't start to click until you finish a small project with it

elements.text: people say that it doesn't start to click until you finish a small project with it

text:
Yeah maybe I should just soldier on. It's just so damn painful.
Don't get me wrong, Julia was painful as well when I was used to Python, but back then I didn't have a choice because Python was too slow :P

elements.text:
Yeah maybe I should just soldier on. It's just so damn painful.
Don't get me wrong, Julia was painful as well when I was used to Python, but back then I didn't have a choice because Python was too slow :P

text: there's a productivity hit for new technologies for sure. So far though I've found it to be really eye opening. I've learned a boatload by trying new stuff. That said - this will probably be my last change for a few years unless something super drastic happens. Rust is pretty awesome

elements.text: there's a productivity hit for new technologies for sure. So far though I've found it to be really eye opening. I've learned a boatload by trying new stuff. That said - this will probably be my last change for a few years unless something super drastic happens. Rust is pretty awesome

elements.text: don't gif up

text:
This time I stopped after doing
`let name = subdir.unwrap().path().as_path().file_name().unwrap().to_str().unwrap().to_owned()` :face_palm: Like, I *get it*, Rust, these are filesystem operations where everything can error, but damn if that isn't verbose

elements.text: This time I stopped after doing
let name = subdir.unwrap().path().as_path().file_name().unwrap().to_str().unwrap().to_owned()
Like, I
get it
, Rust, these are filesystem operations where everything can error, but damn if that isn't verbose

text: By the way, that's the way I figured out for how to convert the content of reading a directory into the file name

elements.text: By the way, that's the way I figured out for how to convert the content of reading a directory into the file name

text: yeaaa that's the price you pay basically...

elements.text: yeaaa that's the price you pay basically...

text: the alternative is trusting your memory management skills though. Which for easy things is fine, but for less easy things, eeek

elements.text: the alternative is trusting your memory management skills though. Which for easy things is fine, but for less easy things, eeek

text: are you sure the operations you need don't exist as APIs?

elements.text: are you sure the operations you need don't exist as APIs?

text: they probably do, but then you have to dig and learn a new ecosystem

elements.text: they probably do, but then you have to dig and learn a new ecosystem

text: Apparently you can do `subdir.unwrap().file_name().into_string().unwrap()` , so that's a little cleaner

elements.text: Apparently you can do
subdir.unwrap().file_name().into_string().unwrap()
, so that's a little cleaner

text: But yeah, 100%, many of these pain points will disappear after getting used to Rust because you learn the idiomatic way of doing it. Just takes months

elements.text: But yeah, 100%, many of these pain points will disappear after getting used to Rust because you learn the idiomatic way of doing it. Just takes months

text: yep, I'm still in the new phase too.

elements.text: yep, I'm still in the new phase too.

text: but its gotten a lot easier

elements.text: but its gotten a lot easier

text: That could be Java if you added a FileNameFactory, or something. :smile:

elements.text: That could be Java if you added a FileNameFactory, or something.

text: Maybe you should use `?` more :stuck_out_tongue: Just to have some distance from all the unwrapping.

elements.text: Maybe you should use
more
Just to have some distance from all the unwrapping.

text: But yeah, once you know what you're building, and also know how to build it the rust way, then making then it feels like most of the time, you're just haggling with the compiler... Which might never get better..

elements.text: But yeah, once you know what you're building, and also know how to build it the rust way, then making then it feels like most of the time, you're just haggling with the compiler... Which might never get better..

text: the thing that slows me down the most so far hasn't been the compiler, but just figuring out what functions exist and what they actually do.

elements.text: the thing that slows me down the most so far hasn't been the compiler, but just figuring out what functions exist and what they actually do.

text:
jakob did you know you can newline method calls?
```subdir
    .unwrap()
    .file_name()
    .into_string()
    .unwrap();```

elements.text: jakob did you know you can newline method calls?

subdir
    .unwrap()
    .file_name()
    .into_string()
    .unwrap();

text: For finding out things that may in the reference, or in edition-book or crates, or anything like that I rely on this browser extension: <https://rust.extension.sh/>
